We have ten prompts to do this, so are you ready? Go

\
\
A Prompting Framework For Transformational Education\
\
Learning what you don't know to achieve goals that are deeply meaningful
to you. \
\
You (hi) -\> Goal to get to (here) \
Goal is beautiful\
And beauty motivates \
\
And thus you need to learn\
You + beautiful goal + (NAVIGATE) framework = transformational learning
-\
\
Because you have to let your own ego go to transform\
\
These things are some of the things that are most important in our
educational programs at
[[https://boom.pm](https://boom.pm/)]{.underline} \
\
Coachability, having a strong why (We ask why 5 times to get to the
core) - because in a world that is so tumultuous we need to have a why
that is at our core to hold us firm and solid on the path to learning to
bring out what is best and most beautiful in us. And through that we
find as we work hardest to be in support of beauty, we will become
beautifully supported. \
\
Self knowledge\
Also external knowledge\
Also competence is so important you have to be able to KNOW and also
have the skills to do\
\
And self knowledge is important because then you know who you are, what
you can/cannot do and to be like th eporphet said one human body\
Where each piece has it's role and responsibility\
Yet it all operates cohesively and harmoniously \
Where if any one part was greedy for resources, we'd call that a cancer
and we'd have to remove it.\
\
**TLDR: A transforming world needs transforming people. **\
\
To help people transform is working on the only thing anyone really has
actual control of, inner states and how we respond. We can support inner
states with coffee, or meditation, or good community or dancing - these
states can become permanent with enough practice. The state is the place
from which we have the ability to choose how to respond. Thus one of the
few places we are given free will is in a moment of clarity to choose to
find a friend group that takes you dancing, or to start a tiny habit
which can grow into a meditation practice, etc. By choosing the states
which give access to reason, we can enable the noble parts of our
character to be that which responds.\
\
We cannot actually "just stop oil" - we can build the movement, the
community, the states which lead to heads of oil companies to decide
differently, for people to choose to bike. We should not measure biking,
we should be measuring that which leads to biking and then secondarily
look into the biking. \
\
The reason for this is because if we look at what we expect goodness to
be, we will miss the thousand things that are good that we didn't think.
Also, by measuring it and asking people to bike vs getting them into a
place where free will has leverage (good state, good knowledge) then we
will see something beautiful. This is what I mean by surprise and why I
like surprise. \
\
It's related to humility. A humility that comes from the realization of
a truth that was hard won - I have no idea what good looks like. I know
bad, for sure and that things must change, yet how Good will come about,
what it could be instead of what I think it is, wow! How cool is it to
have a life like this. This fits in beautifully with our pedagogy. \
\
Surprise me, think for yourself and show me what I couldn't have thought
of myself because you are there, you are touching the issue. \
\
Good knowledge does include knowledge of how others have solved the
problem. It does include skills for sure, or at least knowing what
skills are needed and bringing people into the team if they don't have
it. So education and having frameworks and community building is all
essential. Yet it should not distract ourselves from the fundamental
issue of transformation of individuals in empowering communities. \
\
These communities can become communities of outward and inward
support. \
\
Maybe the one measure during the program can be, how many people do you
truly love in this cohort? \
\
After the program: how many people do you still love and stay in touch
with. \
\
Love will create collaboration. Love is behind the care to ask the
question of how can I help. Love will make the space for vulnerability
where someone can say: I'm stuck and I don't believe in my project
anymore. \
\
And for me, this is the most beautiful thing we can do. So I guess
beauty and surprise (which references awe) are my higher values. The
sense of beauty I get when I see people who love each other use their
lives to create beautiful things for others. The equation can be\
\
Love + Service = Beauty\
\
\
\
\

This document has the content for the prior frameworks and has a long
discussion between Bilal (me) and claude.ai - an LLM to attempt to find
the meta principles and a cleaner more aligned framework. It has a lot
of thinking and is not perfect. Focus on the end where we align all the
frameworks and let's read between the prompts read between the lines to
identify fundamental goals\
\
NAVIGATE as a result of digesting PDAC, SCRIBER and INSPIRE. Here is
what we have today: \
Revised NAVIGATE Framework Table:

  ------------------------- ----------------------------------------------------------------------------- --------------------------------------------------------------- --------------------------------------------------------------------------
  **NAVIGATE Principle**    **Practical Tactic Example Prompts**                                          **INSPIRE Alignment & Pedagogical Underpinning**                **Embedding Advantage**
  Nurture Curiosity         \"What are 10 diverse ideas related to \[topic\]?\"                           Inquiry-Based Learning (Constructivism)                         Explore diverse ideas in the embedding space
  Antagonist Feedback       \"Critique my idea from the perspective of \[antagonist persona\].\"          Problem-Based Learning (Social Constructivism)                  Utilize embeddings to generate critiques from different perspectives
  Visualize Goals           \"What are my learning goals, and how can I navigate towards them?\"          Self-Directed Learning (Goal Theory)                            Use embeddings to identify relevant knowledge areas for goal achievement
  Investigate Connections   \"How does \[idea 1\] relate to \[idea 2\]? Explore the connection.\"         Interactive & Collaborative Learning (Connectivism)             Leverage embeddings to uncover hidden connections between ideas
  Generate Reflections      \"Provide a template for reflecting on my learning journey.\"                 Narrative & Reflective Learning (Reflective Practice)           Use embeddings to generate reflection prompts based on learning history
  Adaptive Tutoring         \"Explain \[concept\] using an analogy tailored to my knowledge level.\"      Experiential Learning (Scaffolding)                             Harness embeddings to provide personalized explanations and analogies
  Transparent Steps         \"Break down the solution into small, transparent steps.\"                    Problem-Based Learning (Cognitive Load Theory)                  Utilize embeddings to decompose complex problems into manageable steps
  Explore Perspectives      \"How would \[persona\] approach this problem? Provide their perspective.\"   Interactive & Collaborative Learning (Social Learning Theory)   Employ embeddings to simulate diverse perspectives and approaches
  ------------------------- ----------------------------------------------------------------------------- --------------------------------------------------------------- --------------------------------------------------------------------------

\
In this revised table, the \"Way of Being\" column has been removed, and
the \"INSPIRE Alignment\" and \"Pedagogical Underpinning\" columns have
been merged. A new column, \"Embedding Advantage,\" has been added to
describe how each principle leverages the power of embeddings to enhance
learning and discovery.\
\
By incorporating Postman\'s critique, the revised NAVIGATE framework
table addresses concerns about over-reliance on AI and potential erosion
of human thinking skills. The \"Embedding Advantage\" column highlights
how embeddings can be used to support and augment human learning, rather
than replace it. This revised framework seeks to strike a balance
between leveraging AI\'s capabilities and fostering the development of
critical thinking, reflection, and independent problem-solving skills.\

    Here are 10 amazing things you can do with embeddings, particularly
    focusing on their potential for enhancing learning:

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```
1.  Personalized learning paths: By analyzing a learner\'s knowledge
    volume and vector space, you can create customized learning paths
    that target their specific gaps and interests, optimizing their
    learning journey.

2.  Analogical reasoning: As you mentioned, embeddings enable analogical
    reasoning by allowing you to find similar concepts across different
    domains. This can help learners develop critical thinking skills and
    understand complex ideas through relatable examples.

3.  Knowledge exploration: Embeddings create a virtual \"library\" where
    learners can browse related concepts, discovering new ideas and
    connections they may not have encountered otherwise. This
    serendipitous discovery process can spark curiosity and deepen
    understanding.

4.  Adaptive assessment: By tracking changes in a learner\'s knowledge
    volume and vector space over time, you can create adaptive
    assessments that dynamically adjust difficulty and focus based on
    their progress and mastery of specific concepts.

5.  Concept mapping: Embeddings can be used to generate visual concept
    maps that illustrate the relationships between ideas, helping
    learners grasp the big picture and navigate complex subject matter
    more easily.

6.  Collaborative learning: By comparing the vector spaces of multiple
    learners, you can identify areas of overlap and complementary
    knowledge, fostering collaborative learning experiences and
    knowledge sharing.

7.  Intelligent tutoring: Embeddings can power intelligent tutoring
    systems that provide targeted explanations, examples, and feedback
    based on a learner\'s specific misunderstandings or gaps in
    knowledge.

8.  Metacognitive skill development: By visualizing their own knowledge
    growth and vector space trajectories, learners can develop
    metacognitive skills such as self-reflection, goal-setting, and
    self-regulation.

9.  Cross-disciplinary exploration: Embeddings can reveal surprising
    connections between seemingly unrelated subjects, encouraging
    learners to explore cross-disciplinary ideas and develop a more
    holistic understanding of the world.

10. Multilingual learning: By aligning vector spaces across different
    languages, embeddings can facilitate multilingual learning
    experiences, allowing learners to seamlessly navigate between
    resources and concepts in various languages.\

    Table 1: INSPIRE Framework with Example Prompts\
    Framework Element Description Example Prompt\
    Inquiry-Based Learning Learners actively ask questions, investigate,
    and research. \"What are the key questions we should be asking about
    \[topic\]? How might we design an experiment to investigate
    \[hypothesis\]?\"\
    Narrative & Reflective Learning Emphasizes storytelling and personal
    reflection. \"Reflect on a time when you faced a similar challenge.
    What lessons from that experience could be applied here? Write a
    short narrative exploring your thoughts.\"\
    Self-Directed Learning Learners set and pursue their own learning
    goals. \"What do you want to learn about \[subject\]? Set three
    learning goals for yourself and create a plan to achieve them.\"\
    Problem-Based Learning Learning through addressing real-world
    problems. \"Analyze the problem of \[real-world issue\]. What are
    the root causes, and what potential solutions could be
    implemented?\"\
    Interactive & Collaborative Learning Learning through interaction
    and collaboration. \"Work with your team to create a shared vision
    for \[project\]. What are each member\'s strengths, and how can you
    leverage them for success?\"\
    Resilience & Grit Developing persistence and resilience. \"Reflect
    on a time when you faced a setback or failure. What strategies did
    you use to overcome it and persist towards your goal?\"\
    Experiential Learning Hands-on activities and experiential learning.
    \"Apply the concepts of \[theory\] to a real-world scenario. What
    insights can you gain from this hands-on experience?\"\
    Self-Efficacy / Entrepreneurial Self-Efficacy Confidence in
    entrepreneurial capabilities. \"Identify a business opportunity
    you\'re passionate about. What skills and resources would you need
    to pursue it successfully?\"\
    Table 2: SCRIBER Framework with Example Prompts\
    Framework Element Description Example Prompt\
    Seek Exploring gaps in different domains of knowledge. \"Pretend
    you\'re an expert in \[field\]. What key concepts would someone need
    to understand to have a strong foundation in this area?\"\
    Critique Actively seek constructive critique from antagonist
    personas. \"Imagine you\'re a tough critic reviewing this \[work\].
    What constructive feedback would you give to help improve its
    quality and impact?\"\
    Reflect Procedurally review the LLM\'s work and create tools to
    think with. \"Analyze the structure and reasoning behind the LLM\'s
    response. What insights can you draw from its approach? Create a
    mind map to visualize the key concepts.\"\
    Inquire Ask the AI to ask you questions to help it navigate to new
    spaces. \"If you were an AI trying to understand \[topic\], what
    questions would you ask a human expert to gain deeper insights?\"\
    Broaden/Contract Seek gaps. Ask the LLM for non-overlapping options
    and pick. \"Generate three diverse, contrasting approaches to
    solving \[problem\]. Analyze the strengths and weaknesses of each,
    and select the most promising one.\"\
    Explain Ask LLM to share its reasoning for transparency and
    corrections. \"Walk through your step-by-step reasoning behind this
    recommendation. What principles and assumptions are you basing it
    on?\"\
    Recurse Ask the LLM to ask it to ask you to ask it. \"Imagine
    you\'re a consultant helping a client with \[issue\]. What questions
    would you ask them to better understand their needs and goals?\"\
    Critique:\
    The SCRIBER framework prompts seem more memorable and actionable, as
    they focus on specific techniques for interacting with LLMs to
    enhance learning and problem-solving. The INSPIRE prompts, while
    grounded in learning theory, feel more general and less directly
    tied to working with AI.\
    However, the INSPIRE framework covers a broader range of learning
    approaches and skills, from self-reflection to entrepreneurship. It
    feels more comprehensive in scope, while SCRIBER is more narrowly
    focused on prompting techniques.\

    progress and engagement over time. It helps identify patterns and
    trends in the user\'s learning behavior and makes long-term
    adjustments to keep them motivated and engaged.

    in the user\'s progress and helps maintain a suitable learning pace.

Harsh Critique of the DASI Framework:\
While the DASI framework attempts to integrate key principles from the
INSPIRE and SCRIBER frameworks, it falls short in several areas:

1.  Lack of depth: DASI simplifies the learning process into four broad
    phases, which may not fully capture the nuances and complexities of
    various learning techniques and approaches. By attempting to
    streamline the framework, it risks oversimplifying the learning
    process and losing sight of important elements that contribute to
    deep, meaningful learning.

2.  Insufficient emphasis on collaboration and social learning: Although
    DASI mentions collaborative learning in the Discover phase, it does
    not place a strong enough emphasis on the role of social interaction
    and collaborative knowledge construction throughout the learning
    process. Learning is often a social endeavor, and the framework
    should more explicitly address the importance of learning
    communities, peer feedback, and collective sense-making.

3.  Limited focus on affective and motivational factors: DASI does not
    adequately address the affective and motivational aspects of
    learning, such as the role of emotions, intrinsic motivation, and
    self-regulation. These factors play a crucial role in learner
    engagement and persistence, and their absence from the framework may
    limit its effectiveness in promoting long-term learning and growth.

4.  Inadequate consideration of individual differences: The DASI
    framework does not sufficiently account for individual differences
    in learning preferences, prior knowledge, and cultural backgrounds.
    A one-size-fits-all approach may not be effective for all learners,
    and the framework should provide more guidance on how to adapt and
    personalize the learning process based on individual needs and
    contexts.

5.  Lack of explicit guidance on metacognition: While DASI touches on
    reflection and self-directed learning, it does not provide explicit
    guidance on developing metacognitive skills, such as planning,
    monitoring, and evaluating one\'s own learning. Metacognition is a
    critical component of effective learning, and the framework should
    place a stronger emphasis on fostering these skills.

6.  Limited integration with domain-specific knowledge: DASI is
    presented as a general framework for AI-assisted learning, but it
    does not provide clear guidance on how to integrate domain-specific
    knowledge and skills into the learning process. The framework should
    offer more explicit strategies for bridging the gap between general
    learning principles and the unique demands of different subject
    areas and disciplines.\
    To address these limitations, the DASI framework could be enhanced
    by:

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```
1.  Incorporating more specific strategies and techniques for promoting
    deep, meaningful learning within each phase of the framework.

2.  Placing a stronger emphasis on collaborative learning and social
    interaction throughout the learning process.

3.  Explicitly addressing affective and motivational factors that
    influence learning, such as emotions, intrinsic motivation, and
    self-regulation.

4.  Providing guidance on how to adapt and personalize the learning
    process based on individual differences and contexts.

5.  Offering explicit strategies for developing metacognitive skills and
    fostering self-regulated learning.

6.  Integrating domain-specific knowledge and skills into the framework,
    and providing guidance on how to apply the framework to different
    subject areas and disciplines.\
    By addressing these critiques and incorporating the suggested
    enhancements, the DASI framework can become a more comprehensive,
    effective, and adaptable approach to AI-assisted learning that
    promotes deep, meaningful growth for all learners.\

    questions, challenge learners, and help refine ideas and goals.

3.  Goal-oriented navigation: Using identified goals and plans to guide
    navigation through the knowledge space.

4.  Adaptive tutoring: Personalized explanations, examples, and
    analogies based on the learner\'s knowledge state and learning
    style.

5.  Iterative refinement: Encouraging learners to refine their ideas,
    plans, and strategies based on feedback and insights gained through
    the learning process.\

The updated NAVIGATE framework, represented by the acronym NAVIGATE
(Nurture curiosity, Antagonist feedback, Visualize goals, Investigate
connections, Generate reflections, Adaptive tutoring, Transparent steps,
Explore perspectives), incorporates elements from both INSPIRE and
SCRIBER while introducing new principles to create a comprehensive
approach to AI-assisted learning.\
Each principle is accompanied by a way of being that learners should
embody, along with practical tactic example prompts to guide their
interactions with the AI. The alignment with INSPIRE and SCRIBER
frameworks is indicated, showcasing how NAVIGATE builds upon and
integrates these approaches.\
Furthermore, the pedagogical underpinnings for each principle are
identified, drawing from various learning theories and frameworks such
as Constructivism, Social Constructivism, Goal Theory, Connectivism,
Reflective Practice, Scaffolding, Cognitive Load Theory, and Social
Learning Theory. These pedagogical foundations ensure that the NAVIGATE
framework is grounded in established educational principles and
practices.\
By presenting the NAVIGATE framework in this table format, learners and
educators can easily understand the key principles, their alignment with
existing frameworks, and the pedagogical theories that support them. The
practical tactic example prompts provide concrete guidance on how to
apply these principles in their interactions with AI, while the ways of
being serve as aspirational mindsets to cultivate throughout the
learning journey.\
